newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian parties hold talks to defuse crisis.
newsitem.headline: Indian parties hold talks to defuse crisis.

text.p: India's ruling coalition and its ally-turned-foe, the Congress Party, were holding talks on Tuesday in an effort to defuse a crisis that has threatened Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's government, politicians said.

They said the right-wing Hindu Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), India's main opposition group, was also talking to both sides to weigh the consequences of Sunday's decision by the Congress to withdraw its make-or-break support for Deve Gowda.
Parliament officials said all the major parties were also locked in talks to rescue the federal budget for fiscal 1997/98 (April-March) from the political chaos.

"A combination of political incest and promiscuity is evident," said a former Congress minister opposed to party president Sitaram Kesri's Sunday decision to topple Deve Gowda and to stake his own claim to form a government.
"The BJP is talking to the Congress through middlemen, the Congress is talking to the United Front, and they are all talking to each other, usually secretly," the politician said.
The Press Trust of India (PTI) quoted Congress officials as confirming that talks were being held between the two former allies.

"We are always for negotiations and without any condition," PTI quoted senior Congress leader K. Karunakaran as telling reporters. He was responding to a question on whether talks were taking place with the United Front.
PTI quoted Congress general secretary Meira Kumar as also confirming that talks were going on with the United Front but she refused say at what level they were being held.
The United Front had urged the Congress on Monday to reconsider its decision to bring down Deve Gowda's government.
Politicians said several options were being considered by both sides, including the replacement of Deve Gowda by someone from the United Front who would be acceptable to the Congress.
Kesri told a news conference on Sunday that he was himself a candidate for Deve Gowda's job.
The ruling coalition officially denied the prime minister's job was negotiable. "The United Front is solidly with Mr Deve Gowda today, and will remain so tomorrow," its spokesman Jaipal Reddy said.
The embattled government moved on Tuesday to win public support with a proposal to get its budget approved by parliament despite the threat to Deve Gowda's political survival.

The United Front said it was confident of getting the budget approved either before a vote of confidence Deve Gowda must face by April 11 or soon afterwards, by proposing a special session of parliament.
"I think we owe it to the country not to force an economic crisis," said Sitaram Yechury, a communist member of the United Front's decision-making Steering Committee.

"This government has generated unprecedented enthusiasm in the country for coalition politics. People will not forgive us if politicians hold the economy to ransom for their narrow ambitions. I am confident the budget will be passed."
The BJP said the budget could be passed only after the trust vote was first considered by parliament. The Congress said it might seek unspecified changes before approving the budget.

President Shankar Dayal Sharma asked Deve Gowda on Monday to face a vote of confidence in parliament by April 7 to prove his majority, but extended the time by four days to allow him to host a meeting of foreign ministers of the Non-Aligned Movement due in New Delhi that day.
The United Front controls only 178 seats in the 545-member in the Lok Sabha. The Congress party had reluctantly shored up the government with its 140 deputies since June.
The BJP and its allies have 194 deputies.
